This collection consists of testimonies, newsletters, selected news articles and other research materials pertaining to the internment of Japanese Americans in the United States during World War II, with specific emphasis on the Commission on Wartime Relocation and Internment of Civilians public hearings. Materials include statements submitted to Wada for the public hearing held in New York City on November 23, 1981 as well as transcripts of the hearing. Additional materials that make up the collection pertain to other hearings held in Washington, D.C. on July 14 and 16, 1981; Cambridge, Massachusetts on December 9, 1981; Los Angeles, California August 4-6, 1981; and Alaska on September 15, 17, and 19, 1981. Materials are in English. Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Scope and Contents
The Takako Wada Papers (dated 1945-1981, bulk 1981) consist of testimonies, newsletters, selected news articles, and other research materials pertaining to the internment of Japanese Americans in the United States during World War II, with specific emphasis on the Commission on Wartime Relocation and Internment of Civilians public hearings. Files include personal statements and testimonies submitted to Takako Wada, English editor of New York Nichibei, a newspaper published by the Japanese American News Corporation, for the public hearing held in New York City on November 23, 1981 as well as transcripts of the hearing. Additional legal transcripts that make up the collection pertain to other hearings held in Washington, D.C. on July 14 and 16, 1981; Cambridge, Massachusetts on December 9, 1981; Los Angeles, California August 4-6, 1981; and Alaska on September 15, 17, and 19, 1981. The witnesses include government officials who ran and supported the internment program, people who were interned and organizations such as the Japanese American Citizens League and American Friends Service Committee.
Biographical Note
Takako "Taxi" Wada (née Kusunoki) was a writer, editor, and activist whose career reflected her interest and involvement in ensuring Asian American civil rights in the United States. Born in Colusa, California, Takako was interned with her mother and two sisters at the Granada relocation camp ("Camp Amache") in Colorado in 1942. As a young adult she spent two years in the Women's Army Corps, worked as a journalist and, studied painting in the studio of Fernand Ledger in Paris on the G.I. Bill of Rights. She was an active supporter of the redress for Japanese Americans who were interned during World War II. In 1981 she closely followed the public hearings held by the Commission for Wartime Relocation and Internment Civilians all across the country. During this time Takako collected testimonies, conducted research, and edited personal statements all pertaining to the hearings, with particular attention paid to those held in Washington D.C., New York, and California. Serving as the English editor for the Japanese-American newspaper New York Nicibei, Takako nurtured and supported topics concerning Asian American rights, women's rights, community service, and arts movements.
Arrangement
This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Materials were donated by Stephanie Wada in January 2017. The accession number associated with this gift is 2018.076.
Conditions Governing Use

Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; Takako Wada Papers; TAM 723; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Processing Information
At the time of accessioning, collection-level finding aid with a brief box list was created to describe this collection. Untitled folders were rehoused into archival housing and given titles based on the general theme of the documents within the folder. Letters were not removed from their original envelopes and were grouped with no specific order in mind. This collection has not been arranged by an archivist; materials were kept in the order they arrived.
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions.
